    2222             : /*
    2223             :  * RelationReloadIndexInfo - reload minimal information for an open index
    2224             :  *
    2225             :  *  This function is used only for indexes.  A relcache inval on an index
    2226             :  *  can mean that its pg_class or pg_index row changed.  There are only
    2227             :  *  very limited changes that are allowed to an existing index's schema,
    2228             :  *  so we can update the relcache entry without a complete rebuild; which
    2229             :  *  is fortunate because we can't rebuild an index entry that is "nailed"
    2230             :  *  and/or in active use.  We support full replacement of the pg_class row,
    2231             :  *  as well as updates of a few simple fields of the pg_index row.
    2232             :  *
    2233             :  *  We can't necessarily reread the catalog rows right away; we might be
    2234             :  *  in a failed transaction when we receive the SI notification.  If so,
    2235             :  *  RelationClearRelation just marks the entry as invalid by setting
    2236             :  *  rd_isvalid to false.  This routine is called to fix the entry when it
    2237             :  *  is next needed.
    2238             :  *
    2239             :  *  We assume that at the time we are called, we have at least AccessShareLock
    2240             :  *  on the target index.  (Note: in the calls from RelationClearRelation,
    2241             :  *  this is legitimate because we know the rel has positive refcount.)
    2242             :  *
    2243             :  *  If the target index is an index on pg_class or pg_index, we'd better have
    2244             :  *  previously gotten at least AccessShareLock on its underlying catalog,
    2245             :  *  else we are at risk of deadlock against someone trying to exclusive-lock
    2246             :  *  the heap and index in that order.  This is ensured in current usage by
    2247             :  *  only applying this to indexes being opened or having positive refcount.

    2932             : /*
    2933             :  * RelationCacheInvalidate
    2934             :  *   Blow away cached relation descriptors that have zero reference counts,
    2935             :  *   and rebuild those with positive reference counts.  Also reset the smgr
    2936             :  *   relation cache and re-read relation mapping data.
    2937             :  *
    2938             :  *   Apart from debug_discard_caches, this is currently used only to recover
    2939             :  *   from SI message buffer overflow, so we do not touch relations having
    2940             :  *   new-in-transaction relfilenumbers; they cannot be targets of cross-backend
    2941             :  *   SI updates (and our own updates now go through a separate linked list
    2942             :  *   that isn't limited by the SI message buffer size).
    2943             :  *
    2944             :  *   We do this in two phases: the first pass deletes deletable items, and
    2945             :  *   the second one rebuilds the rebuildable items.  This is essential for
    2946             :  *   safety, because hash_seq_search only copes with concurrent deletion of
    2947             :  *   the element it is currently visiting.  If a second SI overflow were to
    2948             :  *   occur while we are walking the table, resulting in recursive entry to
    2949             :  *   this routine, we could crash because the inner invocation blows away
    2950             :  *   the entry next to be visited by the outer scan.  But this way is OK,
    2951             :  *   because (a) during the first pass we won't process any more SI messages,
    2952             :  *   so hash_seq_search will complete safely; (b) during the second pass we
    2953             :  *   only hold onto pointers to nondeletable entries.
    2954             :  *
    2955             :  *   The two-phase approach also makes it easy to update relfilenumbers for
    2956             :  *   mapped relations before we do anything else, and to ensure that the
    2957             :  *   second pass processes nailed-in-cache items before other nondeletable
    2958             :  *   items.  This should ensure that system catalogs are up to date before
    2959             :  *   we attempt to use them to reload information about other open relations.
    2960             :  *
    2961             :  *   After those two phases of work having immediate effects, we normally
    2962             :  *   signal any RelationBuildDesc() on the stack to start over.  However, we
    2963             :  *   don't do this if called as part of debug_discard_caches.  Otherwise,
    2964             :  *   RelationBuildDesc() would become an infinite loop.
    2965             :  */

    3910             : /*
    3911             :  * RelationAssumeNewRelfilelocator
    3912             :  *
    3913             :  * Code that modifies pg_class.reltablespace or pg_class.relfilenode must call
    3914             :  * this.  The call shall precede any code that might insert WAL records whose
    3915             :  * replay would modify bytes in the new RelFileLocator, and the call shall follow

    4722             : /*
    4723             :  * RelationGetIndexList -- get a list of OIDs of indexes on this relation
    4724             :  *
    4725             :  * The index list is created only if someone requests it.  We scan pg_index
    4726             :  * to find relevant indexes, and add the list to the relcache entry so that
    4727             :  * we won't have to compute it again.  Note that shared cache inval of a
    4728             :  * relcache entry will delete the old list and set rd_indexvalid to false,
    4729             :  * so that we must recompute the index list on next request.  This handles
    4730             :  * creation or deletion of an index.
    4731             :  *
    4732             :  * Indexes that are marked not indislive are omitted from the returned list.
    4733             :  * Such indexes are expected to be dropped momentarily, and should not be
    4734             :  * touched at all by any caller of this function.
    4735             :  *
    4736             :  * The returned list is guaranteed to be sorted in order by OID.  This is
    4737             :  * needed by the executor, since for index types that we obtain exclusive
    4738             :  * locks on when updating the index, all backends must lock the indexes in
    4739             :  * the same order or we will get deadlocks (see ExecOpenIndices()).  Any
    4740             :  * consistent ordering would do, but ordering by OID is easy.
    4741             :  *
    4742             :  * Since shared cache inval causes the relcache's copy of the list to go away,
    4743             :  * we return a copy of the list palloc'd in the caller's context.  The caller
    4744             :  * may list_free() the returned list after scanning it. This is necessary
    4745             :  * since the caller will typically be doing syscache lookups on the relevant
    4746             :  * indexes, and syscache lookup could cause SI messages to be processed!
    4747             :  *
    4748             :  * In exactly the same way, we update rd_pkindex, which is the OID of the
    4749             :  * relation's primary key index if any, else InvalidOid; and rd_replidindex,
    4750             :  * which is the pg_class OID of an index to be used as the relation's
    4751             :  * replication identity index, or InvalidOid if there is no such index.
    4752             :  */

    4879             :  * relevant statistics, and add the list to the relcache entry so that we
    4880             :  * won't have to compute it again.  Note that shared cache inval of a
    4881             :  * relcache entry will delete the old list and set rd_statvalid to 0,
    4882             :  * so that we must recompute the statistics list on next request.  This
    4883             :  * handles creation or deletion of a statistics object.
    4884             :  *
    4885             :  * The returned list is guaranteed to be sorted in order by OID, although
    4886             :  * this is not currently needed.
    4887             :  *
    4888             :  * Since shared cache inval causes the relcache's copy of the list to go away,
    4889             :  * we return a copy of the list palloc'd in the caller's context.  The caller
    4890             :  * may list_free() the returned list after scanning it. This is necessary
    4891             :  * since the caller will typically be doing syscache lookups on the relevant
    4892             :  * statistics, and syscache lookup could cause SI messages to be processed!

    5184             :  * The result has a bit set for each attribute used anywhere in the index
    5185             :  * definitions of all the indexes on this relation.  (This includes not only
    5186             :  * simple index keys, but attributes used in expressions and partial-index
    5187             :  * predicates.)
    5188             :  *
    5189             :  * Depending on attrKind, a bitmap covering attnums for certain columns is
    5190             :  * returned:
    5191             :  *  INDEX_ATTR_BITMAP_KEY           Columns in non-partial unique indexes not
    5192             :  *                                  in expressions (i.e., usable for FKs)
    5193             :  *  INDEX_ATTR_BITMAP_PRIMARY_KEY   Columns in the table's primary key
    5194             :  *  INDEX_ATTR_BITMAP_IDENTITY_KEY  Columns in the table's replica identity
    5195             :  *                                  index (empty if FULL)
    5196             :  *  INDEX_ATTR_BITMAP_HOT_BLOCKING  Columns that block updates from being HOT
    5197             :  *  INDEX_ATTR_BITMAP_SUMMARIZED    Columns included in summarizing indexes
    5198             :  *
    5199             :  * Attribute numbers are offset by FirstLowInvalidHeapAttributeNumber so that
    5200             :  * we can include system attributes (e.g., OID) in the bitmap representation.
    5201             :  *
    5202             :  * Caller had better hold at least RowExclusiveLock on the target relation
    5203             :  * to ensure it is safe (deadlock-free) for us to take locks on the relation's

    5205             :  * that lock level doesn't guarantee a stable set of indexes, so we have to
    5206             :  * be prepared to retry here in case of a change in the set of indexes.
    5207             :  *
    5208             :  * The returned result is palloc'd in the caller's memory context and should
    5209             :  * be bms_free'd when not needed anymore.

    5988             : 
    5989             : /*
    5990             :  *  load_relcache_init_file, write_relcache_init_file
    5991             :  *
    5992             :  *      In late 1992, we started regularly having databases with more than
    5993             :  *      a thousand classes in them.  With this number of classes, it became
    5994             :  *      critical to do indexed lookups on the system catalogs.
    5995             :  *
    5996             :  *      Bootstrapping these lookups is very hard.  We want to be able to
    5997             :  *      use an index on pg_attribute, for example, but in order to do so,
    5998             :  *      we must have read pg_attribute for the attributes in the index,
    5999             :  *      which implies that we need to use the index.
    6000             :  *
    6001             :  *      In order to get around the problem, we do the following:
    6002             :  *
    6003             :  *         +  When the database system is initialized (at initdb time), we
    6004             :  *            don't use indexes.  We do sequential scans.
    6005             :  *
    6006             :  *         +  When the backend is started up in normal mode, we load an image
    6007             :  *            of the appropriate relation descriptors, in internal format,
    6008             :  *            from an initialization file in the data/base/... directory.
    6009             :  *
    6010             :  *         +  If the initialization file isn't there, then we create the
    6011             :  *            relation descriptors using sequential scans and write 'em to
    6012             :  *            the initialization file for use by subsequent backends.
    6013             :  *
    6014             :  *      As of Postgres 9.0, there is one local initialization file in each
    6015             :  *      database, plus one shared initialization file for shared catalogs.
    6016             :  *
    6017             :  *      We could dispense with the initialization files and just build the
    6018             :  *      critical reldescs the hard way on every backend startup, but that
    6019             :  *      slows down backend startup noticeably.
    6020             :  *
    6021             :  *      We can in fact go further, and save more relcache entries than
    6022             :  *      just the ones that are absolutely critical; this allows us to speed
    6023             :  *      up backend startup by not having to build such entries the hard way.
    6024             :  *      Presently, all the catalog and index entries that are referred to
    6025             :  *      by catcaches are stored in the initialization files.
    6026             :  *
    6027             :  *      The same mechanism that detects when catcache and relcache entries
    6028             :  *      need to be invalidated (due to catalog updates) also arranges to
    6029             :  *      unlink the initialization files when the contents may be out of date.
    6030             :  *      The files will then be rebuilt during the next backend startup.
    6031             :  */
    6032             : 
    6033             : /*
    6034             :  * load_relcache_init_file -- attempt to load cache from the shared
